Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: How Native Chinese Listeners and Second-Language Chinese Learners Process Tones in Word Recognition: An Eye-tracking Study

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Chinese is becoming an increasingly important language on the international scene. Accordingly, it has become a commonly taught language in foreign language programs in the United States, and thus an increasingly large number of native English speakers are learning Chinese. Importantly, Chinese and English differ in the types of information they use to convey meaning in words: unlike English, Chinese uses lexical tones (i.e., pitch movement) to contrast word meanings (e.g., in Chinese, the word "ma" can mean mother, hemp, horse, or scold depending on its lexical tone). This difference between Chinese and English poses word recognition difficulties for English-speaking learners of Chinese. This doctoral dissertation project examines how native Chinese listeners and proficient adult English-speaking learners of Chinese use tonal information in word recognition as the speech signal unfolds in time.

Two visual-world eye-tracking experiments will be conducted to investigate three potential differences between native Chinese listeners and English learners of Chinese in their use of tonal information in word recognition: (i) their potentially different sensitivities to the early pitch height of the tone (high vs. low); (ii) their potentially different sensitivities to fine-grained variability in this early pitch height; and (iii) their potentially different abilities to use the complete pitch contour of the tone. It is hypothesized that the time course of use of tonal information will differ between Chinese and English listeners, with English listeners showing more sensitivity to fine-grained early pitch height information than Chinese listeners (suggesting less categorical perception of lexical tones) but ultimately having more difficulty in using pitch contour information in word recognition. The findings of this research will make an important contribution to the understanding of how tonal information modulates word recognition in native Chinese listeners and English-speaking learners of Chinese, and it will have pedagogical implications for the teaching of Chinese.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This dissertation project examined how native Mandarin speakers and proficient adult English-speaking learners of Mandarin use tonal information in the recognition of Mandarin words.

 

Mandarin poses a unique linguistic challenge to English-speaking learners: Unlike English, Mandarin uses lexical tones (i.e., pitch movement) to contrast word meanings (e.g., in Mandarin, the word "ma" can mean mother, hemp, horse, or scold depending on its lexical tone). Because tonal information is not lexically contrastive in English, English-speaking learners of Mandarin often have difficulty identifying Mandarin tones and using tonal information to recognize Mandarin words. This difficulty can lead English-speaking learners to misunderstand Mandarin words, which may in turn result in communication breakdowns when interacting with native Mandarin speakers. English-speaking learners’ use of tonal information in the recognition of Mandarin words is therefore critical to their ability to communicate in the Mandarin language.

 

Mandarin tones are highly dynamic, requiring listeners to evaluate the height of the pitch they hear in the signal against the pitch range of the talker and continuously update this evaluation as more of the pitch is heard over time. Moreover, Mandarin tones show a great deal of variability in their realization, thus also requiring listeners to evaluate the pitch they hear again the talker's different realizations of the same tone and of different tones. This fine-grained tonal information may be very informative for distinguishing Mandarin words, with a word being easier to recognize if its tone is more distant from the tone of a competing word than if its tone is closer to that of a competing word. 

 

This research used visual-world eye-tracking experiments to examine how listeners use fine-grained tonal information as the speech signal unfolds over time. Native Mandarin speakers and English-speaking learners of Mandarin were tested in two experiments.

 

Experiment 1 investigated listeners incremental use of the early pitch information in Mandarin lexical tones. Participants saw four objects in a display, two of which contained the same consonants and vowels but different tones, with the early pitch in the two tones being either similar (i.e., both tones began with a high pitch) or different (i.e., one tone began with a high pitch and the other tone began with a low pitch). Participants’ fixations to the objects in the display indicated that native Mandarin speakers used this early pitch information as soon as it became available in the speech signal, whereas English-speaking learners of Mandarin started using this information much later, once the rest of the tone had been heard. 

 

Experiment 2 examined listeners’ use of fine-grained within-category tonal information. Participants saw four objects in a display, two of which contained the same consonants and vowels but different tones, with the early pitch of the target tone being phonetically closer to or more distant from the early pitch of the competitor tone compared to the talker's prototypical target tone.Participants’ fixations to the objects in the display demonstrated that when native Mandarin speakers showed an effect of fine-grained tonal information, the directionality of this effect was predicted by the phonetic distance between the early pitch of the target and competitor tones; by contrast, when English-speaking learners of Mandarin showed an effect of fine-grained tonal information, the directionality of this effect was predicted by whether or not the target tone heard was prototypical for the talker. 

 

Native Mandarin speakers’ immediate use of the early pitch information in lexical tones suggests that tonal information is used incrementally as the speech signal unfolds, and their sensitivity to fine-grained within-category tonal information suggests that the speech processing system does not discard this information as spoken words are recognized. Future models of spoken word recognition will need to incorporate both the dynamic and fine-grained nature of pitch information in order to capture the use of this information in spoken word recognition for languages with lexical tones. 

 

English-speaking learners’ difficulty in the rapid use of early tonal information suggests that these learners’ representations of Mandarin lexical tones are not sufficiently robust to allow for the automatic retrieval and early use of this information in spoken word recognition. Additionally, the English-speaking learners’ sensitivity to the prototypicality of the target tone over its phonetic distance from the competitor tone suggests that the learners’ representations of lexical tones are not sufficiently detailed to allow for the relative phonetic distance between tones to be computed. Given these difficulties, Mandarin language teachers should develop perceptual training materials with tonal variability manipulated to draw learners’ attention to the early pitch information as one important cue to Mandarin tones and help them tune in to its fine-grained variations.

 

This project enhanced the student Co-PI’s training in speech processing, and it created opportunities for international research collaborations among the PI and Co-PIs, and the Chinese scholars who hosted the student Co-PI for the purpose of this research.
